channel.title: Frostwire
channel.description:
[center][b][size=18pt]FROSTWIRE[/size][/b][/center]
[center][IMG]http://i141.photobucket.com/albums/r55/ricky904/SAVE_Frostwire.jpg[/img][/center]
[ul][li][b]so what is Frostwire?[/b] - FrostWire, a Gnutella Peer-to-Peer client, is a collaborative effort from many Open Source and freelance developers located from all around the world.[/li][/ul]
Using the most recent version of FrostWire allows users to enjoy the best program functionality. Bugs reported in older versions have been fixed for the latest version. Any users with FrostWire 2.5 or earlier MUST update.
Frostwire's features include:
* Completely Free & Open Source! * Faster Download Speeds * No Spyware. No Adware. Guaranteed. * iTunes™ Compatible! * Faster Torrent Speeds * Friendly Online Chat Rooms * Bittorrent Support! * Even More Connections * New & Improved Skins
FrostWire is a fork of the LimeWire source code, and as such, it functions exactly the same. When you search for a file using FrostWire, you get results from LimeWire, and vice versa.
However, the user experience differs in two ways. One is that the code is actually based on LimeWire Pro, the paid version of the popular P2P client, so users don't have to worry about simultaneous download restrictions, and they won't get bombarded by ads. Also, befitting the name, the interface has changed from green to blue and has been slightly improved. Tabs have rounded corners, and there are two additions, as well. Connections monitors your outgoing and incoming connections by host name, but also provides bandwidth information, the vendor and version being used, and more. There's also a built-in community chat.
When it was tested, the built-in media player in FrostWire didn't work with MP3s or MPGs, although those files worked fine in LimeWire and elsewhere. The app also comes bundled with the ASK toolbar, but you can opt out of that during the installation process. While some people have experienced faster download times with FrostWire compared with its parent, others have not. FrostWire and LimeWire are practically indistinguishable, although the lack of ads is a big plus.
[IMG]http://i164.photobucket.com/albums/u3/samuraixyz/etc/frostwire.jpg[/img] [u]- DID NOT TAKE THAT PICTURE[/u]

item.title: Frostwire
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:63, topic:289599”][quote author=Pwnd link=topic=382799.msg3777953#msg3777953 date=1318232379]
You don’t need to search too hard with bittorrents, so… why bother?
[/quote]

One reason just off the top of my head, if you just want one song, frostwire was much faster and easier than bittorrent.[/quote]Assuming you didn’t give a crap about the quality of said song.

With any decent bittorrent client you could have just singled the song out from a discography. Then again, cool people use usenet.

Read full topic

item.title: Frostwire
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Yes, the content was more than questionable, but that says nothing about the protocol. Eventually I plan to implement gnutella support in my Java resource grabbing library, since gnutella isn’t just 1 network, but can have as many private networks as you want, it might end up being even better and faster than torrent support for downloading large resource files from among a number of different clients.

Still, if you weren’t an idiot, you could find legitimate files on frostwire to download.

Read full topic

Moparisthebest:

That’s ridiculous, why would they have removed Gnutella support?

Mopman:

It hasn’t been a Gnutella client for quite some time, it’s just BitTorrent now. Gnutella is dying a slow death.

item.title: Frostwire
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

BloodRayne:

Another reason I dislike Limewire is because files downloaded from it are usually missing some if not all metadata, leaving just a song name. Me being an organization freak, I like the fact that when I download a song, it’s already organized in my media player with proper album information

it’s usually a double bladed sword, I have downloaded dozens of mislabelled albums with errors ranging from wrong years(most common) to completely mislabelled songs

Read full topic

item.title: Frostwire
item.dc:creator: @bloodrayne bloodrayne
item.description:
@bloodrayne wrote:

Gnutella just sounds dirty.

I ditched Limewire/Frostwire when I found out about torrents simply because the quality of files found with torrents seems to be much higher. With Limewire, you never know exactly what you’re getting. Torrents usually have a good description of the file being downloaded, are high quality(if coming from a trusted source), and you get what you thought you were getting.

Another reason I dislike Limewire is because files downloaded from it are usually missing some if not all metadata, leaving just a song name. Me being an organization freak, I like the fact that when I download a song, it’s already organized in my media player with proper album information

Read full topic
